title: I have 43k in credit card debit, owes $550k in mortgage, no second, but took money out to refin for that loan. loan was 1% optio
question: arm. income greatly reduced, 1 income being unemployment. we cannot pay mortgage at current amount unless i get loan mod. got denied 3 times for loan mod (18mos behind because of appeals) because servicer is not joining the govt mha programs and they do not want to reduce principal. the house market value is $415k, so i owe $135k more than value. house needs major repairs also. i filed for bk7, not discharged yet, but i am thinking to retain the house and once bk7 is discharged, can i go for bk13 to restructure pmts for the house? ongoing rent is about the same as mortgage pmt if loan gets restructured under mha. with bk7, it will be tough to rent.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate finances,Short sales,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Unemployment compensation,Appeals

I say this often... getting advice from an inexperienced bankruptcy lawyer, a bankruptcy mill, a paralegal, a realtor, a neighbor, etc... is like getting medical advice from a mechanic. The best I can tell you is to seek competent counsel that understands BOTH chapter 13 and chapter 7. You may need to convert the case. You cannot file a Chapter 13 until 4 years have passed from your Chapter 7 Discharge. If you are thinking of filing a Chapter 13, you might be better off converting to a Chapter 13 now before you obtain your Chapter 7 discharge. Of course, this really depends on a myriad of decisions and factors. You cannot restructure your loan in a Chapter 13 (unless the lender agrees). So you are pretty much back to where you were before. All that a Chapter 13 does is allow you 3-5 years to make up past due mortgage payments. You have to pay that and still pay what you normally would pay on your current mortgage.

You might want to think about a short sale on your home, because it seems like you really can't afford to keep this home. Most attorneys will not tell you this because it means no potential for legal fees. If you decide to go with the short sale round, you will need a very experienced agent/attorney who knows how to work with banks to obtain their approval. Hope this helps.

You will want to sit down with an experienced Chapter 13 attorney to discuss your entire situation. Chapter 13 is a complex program and you have complicated questions that require an individual answer.

Based on what you are saying, I believe your expectations are not realistic, but the devil is, as they say, in the details.

Hope this perspective helps!
